title: Garamond / Baskerville / Caslon / Bembo
content: hi, i was wondering if anyone here could help me.. i'm trying to find companies/logotypes/products etc. that show exemplar usages of these fonts for my type class .. i've come up with a few on my own so far, but Baskerville is still eluding me.. any help on any of the four fonts [Garamond, Baskerville, Caslon, or Bembo] would be appreciated!
author: bibigoogles

comments.content:
Gallimard, the French publisher, puts Baskerville to hyperclassy use in their "Folio" series of pocket books.   
   
Fitting, since it was the French who saved Baskerville's punches from oblivion at the hands of his own countrymen.   
   
hhp

GE's corporate typefaces are ITC New Baskerville and Univers. Any piece of GE sales literature or packaging should use New Baskerville if a serif typeface is used.   
   
Apple's corporate typeface is condensed Garamond; they use it for absolutely everything.

hmm.. General Electric literature/packaging was already on my list for New Baskerville.. any other suggestions? What does Abode use.. ? is it Caslon?

Adobe seems to use mostly Myriad and Minion.

_The New Yorker_ uses (or used) Adobe Caslon. _Critical Review_ uses Bembo on some nice paper. _First Things_ uses ITC New Baskerville, and while the paper is good I wish they'd switch to a different Baskerville. _The New Criterion_ does wonders with Galliard CC. Strangely, I can't think of any magazines or journals off the top of my head that use a Garamond.

Because Apple want to sell itself to Adobe?   
   
More serious, I don

Go get 'em, Stephen, we're right behind ya! ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20150125063746im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif) Actually, it makes sense, and it would do the world of publishing and graphic design a lot of good, counterbalancing the current emphasis on the "art" director. I once witnessed a discussion between two of those trying to decide which typeface should go on a shopping bag. After half an hour(!) of uninterupted to and fro, one of them suddenly jumped up, a victorious smile on his face, and went: "I've got it! Let's use Helvetica!" Djeeez...

Collect those Univers/Baskerville GE samples while you can. It seems as though GE is changing to Trade Gothic (condensed for body copy!), changing
It looks like a junkyard. How strangely apt.
You guys might be right, but I still think the GE logo is really purty. Always loved it. Adding 3D to it is kinda gratuituous, though...

i'm sorry but I truly hate it. I mean the addition of the _supercool 3d shading_. It reminds me of the Palm logo. Perhaps even more proof that there are no original ideas left. Ironic considering their new slogan.

Yves, I, too, have always liked the GE logo. I hate what they're doing to it.   
   
To me, the punch line is that GE is reportedly spending 1/10 of a billion dollars on this makeover. You don't need to have taste to spend big bucks. The whole thing seems like a bad joke.   
   
I'm really disappointed that they've dropped Baskerville. I always thought it added a lot of class to their materials, plus there were things like small caps and oldstyle figures available. I design some of the trade show graphics for one of GE's businesses, so I'm really depressed with the changes they're implementing.
The original GE logotype is MORE than 100 years old. I believe it was designed in 1894. Definitely 189x...

_Apple's corporate typeface is condensed Garamond_   
   
This may be a seperate discussion, but Apple's [switched](http://web.archive.org/web/20150125063746/http:/a772.g.akamai.net/7/772/51/e53ff95e03e4f6/www.apple.com/switch/whyswitch/images/topten_head06102002.gif)   
almost entirely from their proprietary [Garamond Cond.](http://web.archive.org/web/20150125063746/http:/www.info.apple.com/homepage/images/title-applecare_support.gif) to   
 [Adobe's Myriad](http://web.archive.org/web/20150125063746/http:/www.adobe.com/type/browser/P/P_1706.jhtml). Modernizing, i suppose.

_Adobe seems to use mostly Myriad and Minion._   
   
Which makes Apple's choice of Myriad all the more puzzling. Why mimic Adobe's look?

of design, which endevours to give each client a distinctive   
aesthetic identity. I'm going to try to do something about it.
